column1: # description = Three articles from the Mansi newspaper. Morphological analysis assisted with giellatekno infrastructure.
# text = Зоя Павловна Самбиндалова Ха̄льӯс район Шайтанкат (Ялпыӈ-нёл-па̄вылт) о̄лы.
# text_en = Zoya Pavlovna Sambindalova lives in Shaytanka (Holy-cape-village), Berezovki rayon.
# text = Ма̄ньщи э̄ква Малеевка па̄вылт самын патыс, ётыл омаге-а̄тяге ёт Шайтанка па̄вылн ва̄нтлас.
# text_en = The Mansi woman was born in Maleevka village, later she moved to Shaytanka village with her parents

column4: самын патуӈкве 'to be born', literally 'to fall in the eye'.

column3: N Du Nom PxSg3-N Du Nom PxSg3
column4: literally her mothers, her fathers (Dual markers indicating that they belong together)

column1: # text = Зоя Павловна такви о̄лупсатэ ос рӯтанэ урыл ма̄ньщи газетав ма̄гсыл тох потыртас:
# text_en = Thus Zoya Pavlovna talked to our Mansi newspaper about her life and her relatives.
# text = Ам омам наме Евдокия Ефимовна Лихачёва о̄лыс.
# text_en = My mother's name was Yevdokiya Yefimovna Likhachova.
# text = Рӯтанум Пе̄с Шайтанка па̄вылт о̄лсыт.
# text_en = My relatives were from the old Shaytanka villages.

column4: Not sure whether Пе̄с Шайтанка or Пе̄с Шайтанка па̄выл is the actual name of a village, or  calling it "old" is just descriptive. As Shaytanka is the Russian name of the settlement, I decided to analyse Пе̄с as being and adjective rather than part of the proper name.

column1: # text = Ты пе̄с па̄выл Шайтанканыл ат ве̄рыстат ӯнлыс.
# text_en = This old village is located five kilometres form [present-day] Shaytanka.
# text = Омам потырта̄лыс, Лихачёвыт Нё̄р тапал е̄рныл тыг ёхтысыт.
# text_en = My mother used to say that the Likhachovs came here from the other side of the Ural.
# text = Яныг ащōйкам Ха̄льӯс пӯпколт савалап ня̄врамыг яныгмас, тав 1846 та̄лт самын патыс.
# text_en = My maternal grandfather grew up the the Beryozovo church internate as an orphan, he was born in 1846.

column4: Not sure whether her "great maternal grandfather" is actually her great-grandfather on the mothers side or just a maternal grandfather that was great in some respect. I've never heard anyone using this term so I decided to analyse it as A + N.

column1: # text = А̄тям Павел Васильевич Самбиндалов наме о̄лыс.
# text_en = My father's name was Pavel Vasilevich Sambindalov.
# text = О̄пам Ма̄нья-сӯнт па̄вылныл тыг ёхтыс.
# text_en = My paternal grandfather came here from Manyya-sunt village

column4: lit. The mouth of Many-ya [Small river]

column1: # text = То̄нт, улпыл, хӯл А̄с я̄т алыщлас ос о̄луӈкве тыт хультыс.
# text_en = Then, apparently, he was fishing on the Ob river and remained here to live.
# text = Ма̄нья-сӯнтыт о̄лнэ рӯтанув ёт а̄тям ва̄йхатас, ам иӈ ня̄врамыг о̄лсум, хунь тав та̄н палтаныл ялыс.
# text_en = My father knew our relatives living in Manyya-sunt, I was still a child, when he went to them.

column4: lit. 'to go and return repeatedly', perhaps indicating that he was visiting them more than once.

column1: # text = Ам тай та ма̄т о̄лнэ рӯтанум щар ат ва̄щиньтасанум, нас ва̄глум, тот Самбиндаловыт о̄лэ̄гыт.
# text_en = I didn't really know my relatives that were living there, I only know that Sambindalovs are living there.

column3: V Act Ind Prt ScSg1 OcPl
V Act Ind Prs ScSg1 OcSg
